oai_dc:dc.dc:title: St. Mark United Primitive Baptist Church: south elevation
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Eatherly, Brad, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: St. Mark United Primitive Baptist Church

Color photograph of a historic church viewed from the south. The side elevation has four six-over-six double hung sash windows and a small metal smokestack vent coming out of the side. The structure has a stone and brick foundation and a gabled roof made of tin.

St. Mark United Primitive Baptist Church was originally named Spring Hill Primitive Baptist. The church was part of the Big Harpeth United Primitive Baptist Association of Tennessee. On August 31, 1872, the Association convened at Spring Hill Primitive. This means the congregation dates back to between 1866 and 1872. It is likely that the current building was constructed around 1900. It served as a local school for African-American children until Spring Hill Rosenwald School opened in 1920-21.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American Churches -- Tennessee; Church buildings -- Tennessee; African American schools -- Tennessee
